Feb 27, 2015( Gizmodo: http://gizmodo.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ; Let's all agree on one thing: The Federal Communications Commission passing the strongest net neutrality rules[1] in America's history is a step in the right direction[2]. But that didn't stop an army of naysayers from crowing about an imaginary government takeover of the internet or how the new plan would slash their profits. Some chose half-intelligent ways to make those arguments. Others did some pretty dumb stuff.

Here are some of our favorite crazy statements from America's most concerned leaders. Verizon Might as well start with the dumbest reaction. Verizon, the peddlers of broken fiber optic dreams[3], doesn't like the FCC's plan one bit, and the multibillion-dollar company's army of flacks are being real dipshits about it. Immediately after the vote, Verizon issued a press release drafted in smudged typewriter text and dated February 26, 1934. It's pretty rude:Verizon published the same press release on its corporate blogs. But in lieu of the vintage font, the company posted the release in Morse code:The 1930s line refers to the classic but fatally flawed criticism of the FCC's reclassifying the internet under Title II of the Telecommunications Act of 1934[4]. Indeed, Congress passed the bill in 1934 and President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed it into law. However, the legislation was then overhauled in 1996, and the new rules explicitly give the FCC the right to forbear [5]any part of the law that aren't relevant to regulating the internet. Also, Morse code is awesome, so your isn't funny, Verizon. Comcast Surprise! Comcast doesn't like the FCC's new net neutrality rules either. This is the same company that has a stranglehold on one out of every three internet users in America[6] who have no other choice of provider, so no surprise there. The company has been famously coy[7] about claiming to love net neutrality but refusing to support the policy that would protect it. Here's that line again from Comcast executive vice president David L. Cohen, saying the company embraces the rules and then immediately mocking them, along with another cute 1930s reference:We fully embrace the open Internet principles that have been laid out by President Obama and Chairman Wheeler and that now have been adopted by the FCC. We just don't believe statutory provisions designed for the telephone industry and adopted when Franklin D. Roosevelt was president should be stretched to govern the 21st century Internet. AT#38;T Double surprise! AT...lso doesn't like the rules. The company's Jim Cicconi got a little wispy in his response[8]:Perhaps I'm betraying my years, but in Washington policy circles there has always been tension between those interested in solving problems and those who see policy disputes as a test of ideology. I'd readily admit falling into the former camp, and have the policy scars to prove it.Words words words. This part's just silly, though:Does anyone really think Washington needs yet another partisan fight? Particularly a fight around the Internet, one of the greatest engines of economic growth, investment, and innovation in history?Actually, yes, we should fight for the future of the internet. And yes, we should do it in Washington. Rep. Ted Cruz Ted's at it again[9]. Speaking at the Conservative Political Action Conference, the Tea Party politician recited his anti-Obama speech:Washington wants Obamacare. The people want liberty. Washington wants amnesty. The people want rule of law. Washington wants power over the internet. The people want freedom online. And don't believe President Obama when he says, 'If you like your internet, you can keep your internet'!By the way this guy is one of the top recipients of campaign donations [10]from big cable companies. He's also now in charge of NASA[11]. Rep. Darrell Issa Here's another guy with misguided ideas who's in a frighteningly powerful position. Darrell Issa is the chairman of the House the Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet. The Republican thinks that the FCC's new net neutrality rules will ruin the internet. Which is funny because big tech companies like Apple and Google support net neutrality. Issa said in a statement:Competition in private industry drives prices down. Government regulation ensures a lack of innovation. Hmm, I dunno, seems like my internet bills have been going up, but I can't switch to a cheaper provider because I only have one choice. Seems like we could innovate on that situation a bit. Random Think Tank Guy And then there's Berin Szoka, the president of an all-male think tank called TechFreedom[12], who swoops in with the punchline:Maybe it's finally time to start dismantling the FCC?Just burn it all down. urn:contentItem:5X8M-TNC1-DY1R-B280-00000-00The largest fund manager will be China2019-10-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:33:35ZLexisNexisThe largest fund manager will be China


Cyrus Taraporevala, CEO of State Street Global Advisors, which manages $2.9 trillion in global assets, draws the industry skyline to ten years.
Ten years from now, the largest fund manager will be Chinese, according to State Street CEO Global Advisors (SSGA), which manages $2.9 trillion of global assets. Cyrus Taraporevala believes that the growth expectations of the Chinese investment fund sector, along with the potential of Chinese companies to buy Western managers, will bring about a tremendous change in the landscape.


"In my opinion, China's entry into global capital markets and the rise of Chinese asset management giants will be the biggest change in the history of the sector," he says. "The timing and conditions favor China," he adds. The executive notes that assets under management in China have increased four-fold since 2013, to $1.7 trillion, and are growing at an annual rate of 17%.
This gives scope to huge growth potential, as only 8% of personal financial assets went to funds and the country's regulators try to reposition the capital to move from shadow banking to investment funds.
China has emerged as a key market for foreign asset managers trying to grow globally and capitalise on demographic changes in the world's most populous country.
Taraporevala, who since November 2017 leads the world's third-largest asset investment group, says that digital changes also pose a threat to traditional fund managers. "I would not underestimate the ability of Chinese fintechs to overtake their Western competitors," he says.
"Companies such as Ant Financial and Tencent intend to move from money market assets and deposits to asset management. Just remember how Ant Financiall's money market fund became the world's largest fund in four years."
Landing
SSGA received authorization from the Chinese regulator in December to create an investment manager with only foreign capital. Since then he has hired Alex Sun, of HSBC's Jintrust fund manager, to the new position of China Chief Manager and Charles Zhao, of Janus Henderson, as head of institutions within the country.
Jennifer Johnson, chief operating officer of Franklin Templeton, who manages $690 billion, believes the Asian giant's economy will have far surpassed that of the US in a decade. "I don't know if the biggest asset manager will be Chinese by then, but it will certainly be one that has studied how to do business in China," he admits. "It is clear that you cannot be a great asset manager without a presence in China," she adds. Last week, Wall Street Journal reported that BlackRock, the world's largest manager, negotiates with Chinese Internet giant Tencent a future collaboration to make tools in the Chinese market. BlackRock co-founder Robert Kapito warned last year that Asia's big tech companies pose a threat to traditional asset managers.
